segment.source: Windows Device Portal overview
segment.target: Windows Device Portal overview

segment.source: Learn how the Windows Device Portal lets you configure and manage your device remotely over a network or USB connection.
segment.target: Learn how the Windows Device Portal lets you configure and manage your device remotely over a network or USB connection.

segment.source: Windows Device Portal overview
segment.target: Windows Device Portal overview

segment.source: The Windows Device Portal lets you configure and manage your device remotely over a network or USB connection.
segment.target: The Windows Device Portal lets you configure and manage your device remotely over a network or USB connection.

segment.source: It also provides advanced diagnostic tools to help you troubleshoot and view the real time performance of your Windows device.
segment.target: It also provides advanced diagnostic tools to help you troubleshoot and view the real time performance of your Windows device.

segment.source: The Device Portal is a web server on your device that you can connect to from a web browser on your PC.
segment.target: The Device Portal is a web server on your device that you can connect to from a web browser on your PC.

segment.source: If your device has a web browser, you can also connect locally with the browser on your device.
segment.target: If your device has a web browser, you can also connect locally with the browser on your device.

segment.source: Windows Device Portal is available on each device family, but features and setup vary based on the device's requirements.
segment.target: Windows Device Portal is available on each device family, but features and setup vary based on the device's requirements.

segment.source: This article provides a general description of Device Portal and links to articles with more specific information for each device family.
segment.target: This article provides a general description of Device Portal and links to articles with more specific information for each device family.

segment.source: Everything in the Windows Device Portal is built on top of REST API's that you can use to access the data and control your device programmatically.
segment.target: Everything in the Windows Device Portal is built on top of REST API's that you can use to access the data and control your device programmatically.

segment.source: Setup
segment.target: Setup

segment.source: Each device has specific instructions for connecting to Device Portal, but each requires these general steps:
segment.target: Each device has specific instructions for connecting to Device Portal, but each requires these general steps:

segment.source: Enable Developer Mode and Device Portal on your device.
segment.target: Enable Developer Mode and Device Portal on your device.

segment.source: Connect your device and PC via local network or USB.
segment.target: Connect your device and PC via local network or USB.

segment.source: Navigate to the Device Portal page in your browser.
segment.target: Navigate to the Device Portal page in your browser.

segment.source: This table shows the ports and protcols used by each device family.
segment.target: This table shows the ports and protcols used by each device family.

segment.target: Device family

segment.target: On by default?

segment.target: For device-specific setup instructions, see:

segment.source: Device Portal for HoloLens
segment.target: Device Portal for HoloLens

segment.source: Device Portal for IoT
segment.target: Device Portal for IoT

segment.source: Device Portal for Mobile
segment.target: Device Portal for Mobile

segment.source: Device Portal for Xbox
segment.target: Device Portal for Xbox

segment.source: Device Portal for Desktop
segment.target: Device Portal for Desktop

segment.source: Features
segment.target: Features

segment.source: Toolbar and navigation
segment.target: Toolbar and navigation

segment.source: The toolbar at the top of the page provides access to commonly used status and features.
segment.target: The toolbar at the top of the page provides access to commonly used status and features.

segment.source: Shutdown: Turns off the device.
segment.target: Shutdown: Turns off the device.

segment.source: Restart: Cycles power on the device.
segment.target: Restart: Cycles power on the device.

segment.source: Help: Opens the help page.
segment.target: Help: Opens the help page.

segment.source: Use the links in the navigation pane along the left side of the page to navigate to the available management and monitoring tools for your device.
segment.target: Use the links in the navigation pane along the left side of the page to navigate to the available management and monitoring tools for your device.

segment.source: Tools that are common across devices are described here.
segment.target: Tools that are common across devices are described here.

segment.source: Other options might be available depending on the device.
segment.target: Other options might be available depending on the device.

segment.source: For more info, see the specific page for your device.
segment.target: For more info, see the specific page for your device.

segment.source: Home
segment.target: Home

segment.source: Your Device Portal session starts at the home page.
segment.target: Your Device Portal session starts at the home page.

segment.source: The home page typically has information about the device, such as name and OS version, and preferences that you can set for the device.
segment.target: The home page typically has information about the device, such as name and OS version, and preferences that you can set for the device.

segment.source: Apps
segment.target: Apps

segment.source: Provides install/uninstall and management functionality for AppX packages and bundles on your device.
segment.target: Provides install/uninstall and management functionality for AppX packages and bundles on your device.

segment.source: Device Portal for mobile
segment.target: Device Portal for mobile

segment.source: Installed apps: Remove and start apps.
segment.target: Installed apps: Remove and start apps.

segment.source: Running apps: Lists apps that are running currently.
segment.target: Running apps: Lists apps that are running currently.

segment.source: Install app: Select app packages for installation from a folder on your computer or network.
segment.target: Install app: Select app packages for installation from a folder on your computer or network.

segment.source: Dependency: Add dependencies for the app you are going to install.
segment.target: Dependency: Add dependencies for the app you are going to install.

segment.source: Deploy: Deploy the selected app and dependencies to your device.
segment.target: Deploy: Deploy the selected app and dependencies to your device.

segment.source: To install an app
segment.target: To install an app

segment.source: When you've created an app package, you can remotely install it onto your device.
segment.target: When you've created an app package, you can remotely install it onto your device.

segment.source: After you build it in Visual Studio, an output folder is generated.
segment.target: After you build it in Visual Studio, an output folder is generated.

segment.source: App install
segment.target: App install

segment.source: Click browse and find your app package (.appx).
segment.target: Click browse and find your app package (.appx).

segment.source: Click browse and find the certificate file (.cer).
segment.target: Click browse and find the certificate file (.cer).

segment.source: (Not required on all devices.)
segment.target: (Not required on all devices.)

segment.source: Add dependencies.
segment.target: Add dependencies.

segment.source: If you have more than one, add each one individually.
segment.target: If you have more than one, add each one individually.

segment.source: Under Deploy, click Go.
segment.target: Under Deploy, click Go.

segment.source: To install another app, click the Reset button to clear the fields.
segment.target: To install another app, click the Reset button to clear the fields.

segment.source: To uninstall an app
segment.target: To uninstall an app

segment.source: Ensure that your app is not running.
segment.target: Ensure that your app is not running.

segment.source: If it is, go to 'running apps' and close it.
segment.target: If it is, go to 'running apps' and close it.

segment.source: If you attempt to uninstall while the app is running, it will cause issues when trying to re-install the app.
segment.target: If you attempt to uninstall while the app is running, it will cause issues when trying to re-install the app.

segment.source: Once you're ready, click Uninstall.
segment.target: Once you're ready, click Uninstall.

segment.source: Processes
segment.target: Processes

segment.source: Shows details about currently running processes.
segment.target: Shows details about currently running processes.

segment.source: This includes both apps and system processes.
segment.target: This includes both apps and system processes.

segment.source: Much like the Task Manager on your PC, this page lets you see which processes are currently running as well as their memory usage.
segment.target: Much like the Task Manager on your PC, this page lets you see which processes are currently running as well as their memory usage.

segment.source: On some platforms (Desktop, IoT, and HoloLens) you can terminate processes.
segment.target: On some platforms (Desktop, IoT, and HoloLens) you can terminate processes.

segment.source: Device Portal for mobile
segment.target: Device Portal for mobile

segment.source: Performance
segment.target: Performance

segment.source: Shows real-time graphs of system diagnostic info, like power usage, frame rate, and CPU load.
segment.target: Shows real-time graphs of system diagnostic info, like power usage, frame rate, and CPU load.

segment.source: These are the available metrics:
segment.target: These are the available metrics:

segment.source: CPU: Percent of total available
segment.target: CPU: Percent of total available

segment.source: Memory: Total, in use, available committed, paged, and non-paged
segment.target: Memory: Total, in use, available committed, paged, and non-paged

segment.source: GPU: GPU engine utilization, percent of total available
segment.target: GPU: GPU engine utilization, percent of total available

segment.source: I/O: Reads and writes
segment.target: I/O: Reads and writes

segment.source: Network: Received and sent
segment.target: Network: Received and sent

segment.source: Device Portal for mobile
segment.target: Device Portal for mobile

segment.source: Event Tracing for Windows (ETW)
segment.target: Event Tracing for Windows (ETW)

segment.source: Manages realtime Event Tracing for Windows (ETW) on the device.
segment.target: Manages realtime Event Tracing for Windows (ETW) on the device.

segment.source: Device Portal for mobile
segment.target: Device Portal for mobile

segment.source: Check Hide providers to show the Events list only.
segment.target: Check Hide providers to show the Events list only.

segment.source: Registered providers: Select the ETW provider and the tracing level.
segment.target: Registered providers: Select the ETW provider and the tracing level.

segment.source: Tracing level is one of these values:
segment.target: Tracing level is one of these values:

segment.source: Abnormal exit or termination
segment.target: Abnormal exit or termination

segment.source: Severe errors
segment.target: Severe errors

segment.source: Warnings
segment.target: Warnings

segment.source: Non-error warnings
segment.target: Non-error warnings

segment.source: Detailed trace (*)
segment.target: Detailed trace (*)

segment.source: Click or tap Enable to start tracing.
segment.target: Click or tap Enable to start tracing.

segment.source: The provider is added to the Enabled Providers dropdown.
segment.target: The provider is added to the Enabled Providers dropdown.

segment.source: Custom providers: Select a custom ETW provider and the tracing level.
segment.target: Custom providers: Select a custom ETW provider and the tracing level.

segment.source: Identify the provider by its GUID.
segment.target: Identify the provider by its GUID.

segment.source: Don't include brackets in the GUID.
segment.target: Don't include brackets in the GUID.

segment.source: Enabled providers: Lists the enabled providers.
segment.target: Enabled providers: Lists the enabled providers.

segment.source: Select a provider from the dropdown and click or tap Disable to stop tracing.
segment.target: Select a provider from the dropdown and click or tap Disable to stop tracing.

segment.source: Click or tap Stop all to suspend all tracing.
segment.target: Click or tap Stop all to suspend all tracing.

segment.source: Providers history: Shows the ETW providers that were enabled during the current session.
segment.target: Providers history: Shows the ETW providers that were enabled during the current session.

segment.source: Click or tap Enable to activate a provider that was disabled.
segment.target: Click or tap Enable to activate a provider that was disabled.

segment.source: Click or tap Clear to clear the history.
segment.target: Click or tap Clear to clear the history.

segment.source: Events: Lists ETW events from the selected providers in table format.
segment.target: Events: Lists ETW events from the selected providers in table format.

segment.source: This table is updated in real time.
segment.target: This table is updated in real time.

segment.source: Beneath the table, click the Clear button to delete all ETW events from the table.
segment.target: Beneath the table, click the Clear button to delete all ETW events from the table.

segment.source: This does not disable any providers.
segment.target: This does not disable any providers.

segment.source: You can click Save to file to export the currently collected ETW events to a CSV file locally.
segment.target: You can click Save to file to export the currently collected ETW events to a CSV file locally.

segment.source: For more details on using ETW tracing, see the blogpost about using it to collect real-time logs from your app.
segment.target: For more details on using ETW tracing, see the blogpost about using it to collect real-time logs from your app.

segment.source: Performance tracing
segment.target: Performance tracing

segment.source: Capture Windows Performance Recorder (WPR) traces from your device.
segment.target: Capture Windows Performance Recorder (WPR) traces from your device.

segment.source: Device Portal for mobile
segment.target: Device Portal for mobile

segment.source: Available profiles: Select the WPR profile from the dropdown, and click or tap Start to start tracing.
segment.target: Available profiles: Select the WPR profile from the dropdown, and click or tap Start to start tracing.

segment.source: Custom profiles: Click or tap Browse to choose a WPR profile from your PC.
segment.target: Custom profiles: Click or tap Browse to choose a WPR profile from your PC.

segment.source: Click or tap Upload and start to start tracing.
segment.target: Click or tap Upload and start to start tracing.

segment.source: To stop the trace, click Stop.
segment.target: To stop the trace, click Stop.

segment.source: Stay on this page until the trace file (.ETL) has completed downloading.
segment.target: Stay on this page until the trace file (.ETL) has completed downloading.

segment.source: Captured ETL files can be opened for analysis in Windows Performance Analyzer.
segment.target: Captured ETL files can be opened for analysis in Windows Performance Analyzer.

segment.source: Devices
segment.target: Devices

segment.source: Enumerates all peripherals attached to your device.
segment.target: Enumerates all peripherals attached to your device.

segment.source: Device Portal for mobile
segment.target: Device Portal for mobile

segment.source: Networking
segment.target: Networking

segment.source: Manages network connections on the device.
segment.target: Manages network connections on the device.

segment.source: Unless you are connected to Device Portal via USB, changing these settings will likely disconnect you from Device Portal.
segment.target: Unless you are connected to Device Portal via USB, changing these settings will likely disconnect you from Device Portal.

segment.source: Profiles: Select a different WiFi profile to use.
segment.target: Profiles: Select a different WiFi profile to use.

segment.source: Available networks: The WiFi networks available to the device.
segment.target: Available networks: The WiFi networks available to the device.

segment.source: Clicking or tapping on a network will allow you to connect to it and supply a passkey if needed.
segment.target: Clicking or tapping on a network will allow you to connect to it and supply a passkey if needed.

segment.source: Note: Device Portal does not yet support Enterprise Authentication.
segment.target: Note: Device Portal does not yet support Enterprise Authentication.

segment.source: Device Portal for mobile
segment.target: Device Portal for mobile

segment.source: Service Features and Notes
segment.target: Service Features and Notes

segment.source: DNS-SD
segment.target: DNS-SD

segment.source: Device Portal advertises its presence on the local network using DNS-SD.
segment.target: Device Portal advertises its presence on the local network using DNS-SD.

segment.source: All Device Portal instances, regardless of their device type, advertise under "WDP._wdp._tcp.local".
segment.target: All Device Portal instances, regardless of their device type, advertise under "WDP._wdp._tcp.local".

segment.source: The TXT records for the service instance provide the following:
segment.target: The TXT records for the service instance provide the following:

segment.source: Key
segment.target: Key

segment.source: Type
segment.target: Type

segment.source: Description
segment.target: Description

segment.source: S
segment.target: S

segment.source: int
segment.target: int

segment.source: Secure port for Device Portal.
segment.target: Secure port for Device Portal.

segment.source: If 0 (zero), Device Portal is not listening for HTTPS connections.
segment.target: If 0 (zero), Device Portal is not listening for HTTPS connections.

segment.source: D
segment.target: D

segment.source: string
segment.target: string

segment.source: Type of device.
segment.target: Type of device.

segment.source: This will be in the format "Windows.*", e.g. Windows.Xbox or Windows.Desktop
segment.target: This will be in the format "Windows.*", e.g. Windows.Xbox or Windows.Desktop

segment.source: A
segment.target: A

segment.source: string
segment.target: string

segment.source: Device architecture.
segment.target: Device architecture.

segment.source: This will be ARM, x86, or AMD64.
segment.target: This will be ARM, x86, or AMD64.

segment.source: T
segment.target: T

segment.source: null-character delineated list of strings
segment.target: null-character delineated list of strings

segment.source: User-applied tags for the device.
segment.target: User-applied tags for the device.

segment.source: See the Tags REST API for how to use this.
segment.target: See the Tags REST API for how to use this.

segment.source: List is double-null terminated.
segment.target: List is double-null terminated.

segment.source: Connecting on the HTTPS port is suggested, as not all devices are listening on the HTTP port advertised by the DNS-SD record.
segment.target: Connecting on the HTTPS port is suggested, as not all devices are listening on the HTTP port advertised by the DNS-SD record.

segment.source: CSRF Protection and Scripting
segment.target: CSRF Protection and Scripting

segment.source: In order to protect against CSRF attacks, a unique token is required on all non-GET requests.
segment.target: In order to protect against CSRF attacks, a unique token is required on all non-GET requests.

segment.source: This token, the X-CSRF-Token request header, is derived from a session cookie, CSRF-Token.
segment.target: This token, the X-CSRF-Token request header, is derived from a session cookie, CSRF-Token.

segment.source: In the Device Portal web UI, the CSRF-Token cookie is copied into the X-CSRF-Token header on each request.
segment.target: In the Device Portal web UI, the CSRF-Token cookie is copied into the X-CSRF-Token header on each request.

segment.source: Important This protection prevents usages of the REST APIs from a standalone client (e.g. command-line utilities).
segment.target: Important This protection prevents usages of the REST APIs from a standalone client (e.g. command-line utilities).

segment.source: This can be solved in 3 ways:
segment.target: This can be solved in 3 ways:

segment.source: Use of the "auto-" username.
segment.target: Use of the "auto-" username.

segment.source: Clients that prepend "auto-" to their username will bypass CSRF protection.
segment.target: Clients that prepend "auto-" to their username will bypass CSRF protection.

segment.source: It is important that this username not be used to log in to Device Portal through the browser, as it will open up the service to CSRF attacks.
segment.target: It is important that this username not be used to log in to Device Portal through the browser, as it will open up the service to CSRF attacks.

segment.source: Example: If Device Portal's username is "admin", should be used to bypass CSRF protection.
segment.target: Example: If Device Portal's username is "admin", should be used to bypass CSRF protection.

segment.source: Implement the cookie-to-header scheme in the client.
segment.target: Implement the cookie-to-header scheme in the client.

segment.source: This requires a GET request to establish the session cookie, and then the inclusion of both the header and the cookie on all subsequent requests.
segment.target: This requires a GET request to establish the session cookie, and then the inclusion of both the header and the cookie on all subsequent requests.

segment.source: Disable authentication and use HTTP.
segment.target: Disable authentication and use HTTP.

segment.source: CSRF protection only applies to HTTPS endpoints, so connections on HTTP endpoints will not need to do either of the above.
segment.target: CSRF protection only applies to HTTPS endpoints, so connections on HTTP endpoints will not need to do either of the above.

segment.source: Note: a username that begins with "auto-" will not be able to log into Device Portal via the browser.
segment.target: Note: a username that begins with "auto-" will not be able to log into Device Portal via the browser.
